evolve::LSystem

evolve::LSystem Class Reference

#include <LSystem.h>

Inheritance diagram for evolve::LSystem:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

LSystem class reads in a file containing a string an information on how to evolve that string, namely probablities of change, and values and positions to chance.

Rules for Mutations

Mutation Probabilites for evolving are as follows: The probabilities consists of type/probability pairs The pairs determine the evolution as follows: the probability is represented as an integer with the smallest increment being 1/100 of a percent. (the increment size may vary from implementation to implementation)
the value stored * 0.0001 gives the percentage as a decimal or the percent *.01 that the second will have any affect. The second entry determines the type of mutation operation to perform.

Growth Rules Similar to the options entry, except replacement happens in a deterministic fashion (instead of the probabilistic replacement strategy employed by mutation options). Currently the string is scanned every step, and each entry checked for eligibility against all the production rules

Unless otherwise noted, methods which return bool return true on success, false on failure.
Unless otherwise noted, the debug or printDebug argument to each method indicated whether or to display debug messages.

virtual const bool evolve::LSystem::getCopy ( System *&  copy,
bool  printDebug = DO_DEBUG 
) [pure virtual]

Returns a copy of this lsystem.

Not implemented as copy constructor to allow for different behavior in case of LSystemInterface, etc, where you don't want a copy of the object itself, rather it creates a remote copy on the server and returns an object controlling that remote copy. It returns a pointer so any LSystem type can be returned

Parameters:
a pointer pointing at a copy of this lsystem. if this pointer is not set to null delete will be called on the pointer, and any info pointed at will be lost. In addtion, if it is not set to null, and points at nothing, undefined behavior may result. Initialize your pointers!
Returns:
true on success, false on failure *

Implemented in evolve::LSystemGeneric.

virtual bool evolve::LSystem::cross ( System *  lsystem,
const map< string, string > &  systemCrossMap,
const map< string, string > &  optionsCrossMap,
const map< string, string > &  mutationProbabilitiesCrossMap,
const map< string, string > &  growthRulesCrossMap,
bool  printDebug = DO_DEBUG 
) [pure virtual]

Crosses this lsystem with another lsystem.

The system cross maps and the options crossMap are structured as follows:
The key can be random:[number], [number]:random, random:random or [number]:[number],
where the random keyword specifies the index to use should be choosen at random.
Otherwise, the key is assumed to be a number that indicates the index to use. The operation to the left of the colon always refers to this object,
while the operation on the right refers to the LSystem object being passed to the method.
The value is an integer 1-3, that specifies which operation to use, as follows:
1) move the element at the index in this system to the index in the other system (1->2)
2) move the element at the index in the other system to this system (2->1)
3) swap elements at this index

Parameters:
lsystem the lsystem to cross this system with
systemCrossMap rules for crossing the existing system (see method dec.)
optionsCrossMap rules for crossing the options (see method dec.) The mutation probabilities cross map is similar, except [number] is the number indicating the type of mutation to alter the probability on.
Operations are specified identically
growthRulesCrossMap The growth crossMap is keyed similarly, but like so: random:[start], etc, where [start] is the start of the production.
Operations are specified identically.
Note to extenders of this class... yes the interface isn't perfect, not too general, but remember, you just need to respect the argument *types*, and you can change the semantics all you want. Just be sure to doc your stuff..
